abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Pension Reform
            Adjustment Loan Project in Peru are as follows: overall
            outcome of the project was rated satisfactory, and the
            performance of the Bank and the Borrower were also rated
            satisfactory. Some of the lessons learned from the project
            are: 1) long-term Government commitment to the project is
            central to success. Persistence and flexibility are
            necessary for pension reform, since the success of new
            institutions requires changes in attitudes of Government
            officials and active and retired employees, and gradual
            adjustments in terms and levels of benefits to attenuate
            political and social impacts. A healthy economy that
            generates successful investment results for the Private
            Pension Fund (AFPs) is a precondition for shrinkage of the
            National Pension System (SNP). Traditional public pension
            systems lack adequate records or controls, and thus priority
            should be given to creating an adequate information base to
            control expenditures and project future costs; and 2) the
            Bank should provide for ongoing supervision and follow-up in
            pension reform which involves complex issues and requires
            multi-year involvement.
